Posts.Content: Jan 5, 2013 04:11PM luvmimom wrote: Thanks everyone. Mom goes into surgery Monday and hopefully we will learn more. Trying to be optimistic. Good news is that her pleural effusion is still resolved after one year. Trying not to figure it out all on my own since I am not a Dr!
Posts.Title: mets to ovaries? luvmimom luvmimom

Posts.Content: luvmimom wrote: Hello ~ my mom was diagnosed stage IV one year ago last December. All they were able to find was small mets in her pleura and she presented with a plueral effusion. She has been on hormonals for one year and has been doing well. She started with 3 months of Xeloda but went on a break due to weight loss and fluid gain in the legs, tried the hormonal, and the hormonal ended up working better for her. The effusion resolved. She had a bone scan at diagnosis, some imaging of her lungs but that's about it. No PET scan. She was diagnosed Stage 1, I believe, 15 years prior to the Stage IV diagnosis. I think she is ER+/PR+ HER- She's had abdominal discomfort for about 3 weeks now and went to see her PCP. They ordered an MRI and called her in today to OBGYN to explain to her that she has a large cyst on one ovary, some fluid buildup around one ovary, something they can't tell what it is beside one of the ovaries, and that her ovaries "did not look quite right"--that's what I got from her translation of the appt today. They are doing some more blood tests and deciding where to send her to surgery so she can have her ovaries removed and I guess, biopsied. So, we don't know if this is a new cancer (ovarian?) or mets yet of course. I just don't know what questions I should be asking. The OBGYNs will handle the surgery, and her ONC will be informed of findings if needed. I guess I am just asking if anyone has had experience with this ~ ovarian mets, or fluid around the ovary, and are there other treatments they can try? I think it's a little weird that they do not do more imaging on her ~ check her liver, etc. Does anyone else here go to Kaiser Northern California? I think Kaiser does not believe in a lot of imaging. Are there questions we should be asking the surgeon? Drs? Anyway, aside from the concern that it's cancer, she's also in a lot of pain. Not too bloated but the Dr said the fluid is sloshing up against the bowel making things uncomfortable. Thanks so much and happy new year to you all! Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: mets to ovaries? luvmimom luvmimom

Posts.Content: Aug 5, 2014 07:02PM luvmimom wrote: Praying it is benign. I agree with the other ladies here. Please take it one day at a time for your mother's sake and stay positive or her. The last thing she needs is other people's worry. This is the road of stage IV and as a daughter of a stage IV mom we just need to look at today and wait for the results. There are plenty of options if it is a brain met but don't go there yet. Every scan, appt, and test can bring a new "what if?" Catastrophic thinking -- something I am guilty of -- won't help you enjoy the possibility of sharing a wonderful summer weekend with your mom. Hugs to you and thinking good thoughts for your mom.
Posts.Title: Possible brain met Lindseyc Lindseyc

Posts.Content: luvmimom wrote: Hello. I just came from my semi annual breast exam with a clinician and she had an ultrasound machine in her office. She took at one cyst and saw it was a cyst, then she took a look at another section where she felt a tiny lump and said it's sending an echo back like a cyst but from one angle it looks triangular maybe. But she's not a radiologist. Is this wise to get these ultrasounds done in office. Does it cause more worry then good? Because now I am freaked out. One minute she was reassuring, the next not so much, then she said 95% of patients she sends to radiology come back with benign conditions. I've never had this done in office before, but she's new so I was curious. I go for a follow up MRI and ultrasound next week. Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: In office ultrasound as opposed to Radiologist Ultrasound luvmimom luvmimom

Posts.Content: Mar 4, 2018 09:43AM luvmimom wrote: Thanks so much ... your information is really helpful. If this ends up benign definately brings up an important point about too much info in the drs office. The nurse practitioner she replaced did breast care for years, was on the tumor board, and always just sent me to imaging when she felt something. My mom died of ILC so I'm extra anxious. She said it was small, 2mm, similar to a cyst, but somewhat of a triangle shape, in an area of increased density on mammo (which us why she was extra cautious in that area) and if it were cancer would be invasive and not in situ... but could be cyst or complex cyst. My head spun. Looked like a round cyst to me, but at one angle it did have a sharp edge. Anyway, I think its best to ask to go straight to the experts next time. That said, if she's found early cancer by being extra vigilant I will be singing her praises no doubt. I can't feel the lump she felt ... she said no one would have felt it in a regular breast exam. And my mammo 3 months ago came back ok. Even the dense part. We shall see.

Posts.Content: Dec 28, 2011 10:56AM luvmimom wrote: Hi Reesie Thanks for your reply. Cancer cells were confirmed in the 2nd fluid draw (none found in first fluid biopsy but pulmonologist wanted to be sure when the fluid built up again so she sent ALL the fluid off the next time) So far that is the only mets. Shortness of breath and pain brought her into the er before Thanksgiving and shes getting drained about every two weeks. She had a bad bought of pneumomia in July and has not felt very good since.
Posts.Title: Mom just diagnosed luvmimom nancyh

Posts.Content: luvmimom wrote: Hi Everyone ~ I've been reading this discussion board since my mom was diagnosed with a stage iv reoccurance after 13 years after her initial diagnosis. I want to thank you all. This is the only place I have gone to learn and your strength and courage is inspiring. I share some of your stories with my mom as she is not ready to jump online quite yet. Mom was diagnosed with a malignant pleural effusion a few weeks ago. Her cancer is HE+ There appear to be no tumors in her lungs, liver and her bone scan was clean. Her oncologist suspects there are little "active spots" on the plueral lining that are causing the irritation which leads to the effusion that he saw on the MRI. Her pulmonologist disagrees and does not think it is cancer. They did not do a PET scan. Of course since there are cancer cells in the lung the onc told her she was a stage 4. She started chemo Monday with the hopes that the effusion will clear up over time and in 4-6 months she can switch to hormone treatment and keep the cancer under control for awhile. He has not talked to her in great detail about a prognosis. My mom is 69. I love her so much. What can I do for her at this point? I feel like I don't know what to say or not to say. I just want to be there for her. Also, has anyone had any experience with plueral effusions? And, if anyone is in CA, has anyone had experience being treated at Kaiser Permanente? I've been a member for a decade, they are new to the HMO and any advice would be great. Thanks so much for being here. God Bless ~ Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Mom just diagnosed luvmimom nancyh

Posts.Content: Mar 2, 2018 02:43PM luvmimom wrote: Thank you for your reply. They scheduled me for a follow up Mammogram and Ultrasound. Whatever she found was about 2mm in size. She is a Physicians Assistant. We have a breast clinic where I had been evaluated for years by a nurse practicioner who had been there forever. She is new and said today "She is learning on the job" I'm an anxious type, so I'm wondering if an ultrasound in office causes more anxiety. She said it looks similar to a cyct and her machine is about 10 years old. The shape and size had her concerned enough to do follow up.
Posts.Title: In office ultrasound as opposed to Radiologist Ultrasound luvmimom luvmimom

Posts.Content: luvmimom wrote: I typically do not post in this forum, but I have read it every day since my mom's Stage IV diagnosis on December 13, 2011. I gained so much knowledge from all of your experiences that I was able to really help my mom make choices about her treatment, and understand what she was experiencing--especially with her ILC abdominal mets. We would have been lost without you all. I thank you from the bottom of my heart. I will share what I posted on Facebook yesterday. We are going to write her obituary this weekend. I do reference "journey" in the beginning, and I've just read through the thread of how offensive that word can be to some. I am having a hard time coming up with the right word. She was diagnosed Stage II fifteen years ago and Stage IV almost three years ago. I wanted people to understand that it was not a battle those 18 years, or even every day the last three years . . . but once diagnosed 18 years ago at an early stage, it never left her thoughts or life. And I wanted people to every understand that it comes back. It lays in wait for years. She did everything "right" Mammograms every year, follow up year since her original diagnosis, etc and she still died of this wretched horrid disease. In some ways it was a journey for her--a change in her perspective on life. She was so brave, but also disappointed and afraid. Who wouldn't be? She loved us all so much. I miss her so much. Here it goes: It's with a heavy heart that I write my dear mother Pat passed away Wednesday morning after an 18 year journey with breast cancer. She died peacefully in the arms of her husband of nearly 50 years. It seems strange to use "cancer" and "peaceful" in the same paragraph. There is nothing really peaceful about cancer. She loved her family and those close to her with all her heart. She gave and gave to us every day--whether it was a shopping trip, a home cooked meal, or one of her many hand crafted cards. The void left by her passing is immediately present. She was so stoic, and even in the end when she decided to no longer treat her progressing disease, she fought for life. She accepted her death, but was brave enough to express the disappointment of leaving her family behind. She loved her two grandchildren--my children--with all her heart and it broke her heart to leave them, as well as my father. My heart grieves for my children who are only 2 1/2 and 5. They lost a one-of-a-kind grandmother too early. It just does not feel fair. It's not fair. It never is. Many of you have met my mother through the years. I thank those who have already sent their condolences. I just ask if you read this, please take a moment today to do something really nice for someone you love. Buy them a special gift. Take them out for coffee. Tell them how much you love them and how important they are to you. Sent them a hand written letter explaining how lovely the view  is out your window. May be try making the card yourself! You may be the only person that does something really special for someone today. It matters. We are left heartbroken, but are comforted by all the memories. Love is eternal. I love you mom.   Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: My mom is an angel luvmimom Fitztwins

Posts.Title: Anyone with single lung met...and no other mets anywhere else? wrsmith2x LindaE54

Posts.Content: luvmimom wrote: Mom just got out of surgery. She had her ovaries removed and the surgeon said there was glue like bc cancer on her stomach lining. She was kind of negative basically telling us that moms demise could be starving to death because its slowing down the bowel. She tried to alleviate a little bowel obstruction. So, what is the prognosis with mets to stomach lining. She is ER+ PR+ HER- and has been on hormonals since March. Her plueral effusion has been resolved (diagnosed 12/11) but now this is a new problem. Are surgeons always this grim when they can't fix everything. Is there hope chemo can help? She has not done a full treatment yet with chemo, only arimedex. Xeloda for a few months but she went off of it when she had the stomach flu and did well on hormonals. Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Dismal talk with surgeon luvmimom Judi1952

Posts.Content: Jan 9, 2013 03:15PM luvmimom wrote: Thanks Everyone. Universal resounding theme here is don't talk to the surgeon about prognosis. My mom goes in for a follow up with her surgeon before she sees her MO, so I hope the surgeon does not scare her. Looked at my mom's original mastectomy records from 1997 and she actually had ILC, so the metastisis in this area makes sense, although her MO told her on the phone this morning that getting it in these areas was rare (I thought she had IDC) She has a great MO. Called this morning himself just to check on how she is feeling and can he prescribe anything for her symptoms. He wants her to recover for 2x weeks then they will put her treatment plan together. Hopefully we can get some shrinkage of that cancer in the abdomen so it stops twisting her bowel.
Posts.Title: Dismal talk with surgeon luvmimom Judi1952

We need to meet with her onc and get a treatment plan together. And its a good thing that she has never had a full chemo treatment yet. Many options out there. The whole image of the glue shutting down her bowel has me worried.
